title: HRT sold counter time
story: Share this article Menopause occurs when a woman stops having periods, meaning she is no longer able to get pregnant naturally.The process — which is triggered by the ovaries producing less oestrogen — is a natural part of ageing and usually occurs between the ages of 45 and 55. The NHS says many menopausal women will suffer from a catalogue of symptoms, some of which can be 'severe'. HRT is one way of treating the symptoms. It restores the levels of female hormones, bringing relief to hundreds of thousands of women each year.Doctors warn some types of HRT can raise the risk of breast cancer, but insists that the benefits outweigh the risks.The Telegraph claimed the aim of making HRT available to women over the counter was to improve access.  Reacting to the news, Haitham Hamoda, chair of the British Menopause Society, said: 'Improving access to HRT is a good thing.'But it is really important that women can access all the help and advice they need.'It's great there is so much conversation about menopause now, and people are far more open about it. 'But we don't want this to come down to a question of self-diagnosis – it's really important that those thinking about starting HRT get the right information.'Clare Murphy, chief executive of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, said: 'Improving access to HRT as well as abortion and contraception is really important for women, so this is extremely welcome news.' The move comes after a lengthy campaign to improve access to HRT and reduce the cost for those who receive it on prescription.And it follows on the heels of the contraceptive pill being made available over the counter for the first time since it was licensed 60 years ago.The MHRA approved two brands of the contraceptive, called Lovima and Hana, to be made available without written authorisation.MPs said at the time that the change would reduce the risk of unplanned pregnancies and abortions, and relieve pressure on GPs. A spokesman for the Department of Health and Social Care said: 'We understand that, for some women, menopause symptoms can have a significant impact on their quality of life and we are committed to improving the care and support they receive.'The spokesman added that the menopause and improving access to HRT would be a 'priority' under the new Women's Health Strategy, which is being developed.Hormone replacement therapy to be sold over the counter for first time

story: Share this article'It is so important that the government urgently comes forward with the long-term funding TfL desperately needs so we can keep services running and deliver much-needed improvements to our transport infrastructure,' he warned earlier this month.The Labour party mayor, re-elected last year for a second term, is reluctantly proposing to raise the compulsory housing tax in the next budget, which he has said would 'unfairly punish Londoners for the way the pandemic has hit our transport network'.He wants the government to inject around £1.7billion to fund TfL until April 2023. However, the Department for Transport has said Mr Khan is responsible for getting the system 'back onto a sustainable financial footing in a way that is fair to taxpayers, rather than continuing to push for bailouts'.'We will continue to discuss further funding requirements with TfL and the Mayor,' a spokesman said this week. The standoff reflects the inevitable rivalry between Mr Khan, touted as a potential future Labour leader, and the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson, himself a former London mayor. Both have accused each other of mismanaging the capital's extensive transport system. TfL notes the pandemic has 'devastated' its accounts, with fares revenue falling by 95 per cent at the height of the first coronavirus wave in 2020.It has been forced to dip into its cash reserves to keep services running while going cap in hand to the government for support.Mr Johnson's administration has already pledged £4billion in subsidies to keep the system running, as well as £600 million in loans.The financial crisis has also affected the capital's new east-west Crossrail route, formally known as the Elizabeth Line, with the stretched budget adding to delays and costs.Other global cities have faced similar struggles, including Ile-de-France Mobilites (IDFM) in the Paris area, which needed government support in its 2020 and 2021 budgets.Meanwhile in the United States, 'strong' financial support packages passed by Congress and the White House helped replace ticket revenues lost from lockdowns, according to Paul Skoutelas, head of the American Public Transportation Association, an industry organisation. But TfL, which gets nearly two-thirds of its operating income from fares - a much higher proportion compared to New York or Paris, where it is more like 40 per cent - has been left especially exposed.'Pre-Covid, TfL was largely self-sustained,' explained Taku Fujiyama, who leads University College London's railway research group, noting it received no major central government grants.'Some cost-cutting measures are on the table now,' he said, adding dramatic line closures were unlikely but minor service changes 'might happen'.'TfL needs to play a delicate game,' Mr Fujiyama told AFP. 'The central government would not give blank cheques, and the TfL would need to demonstrate their effort, whilst the mayor knows that dramatic service reduction would be politically costly.'With the threat from the Omicron variant now receding, passengers are returning to the system, aiding revenues but still leaving a large gap to plug.Weekday passenger numbers were at 50 per cent of pre-pandemic levels on the Tube and 70 per cent on buses in mid-January, with TfL expecting them both to reach 80 per cent this year.The organisation has said it is exploring a number of ways to boost income, including through efficiency gains, commercial property projects and consultancy services.

title: about 80 per cent of eligible people have received covid booster nphet says
story: Deputy chief medical officer Ronan Glynn said demand for booster vaccines has decreased since the record demand experienced over the Christmas and New Year period. File photograph: Nick BradshawAn estimated 80 per cent of those eligible for a booster vaccine have received the jab, public health officials have said.The National Public Health Emergency Team (Nphet) said that in “broad terms”, it is satisfied with the level of protection in place against Covid-19 in the State.Speaking at a meeting of the Oireachtas Health Committee on Wednesday, Ronan Glynn, deputy chief medical officer, said demand for booster vaccines has decreased since the record demand experienced over the Christmas and New Year period.“There are a variety of reasons for that. We think that if you take the proportion of people who have been boosted and then the proportion of people who can’t be boosted because they’ve been recently infected… we estimate that about 80 per cent of all those eligible to be boosted have been boosted,” he said.There is currently no recommendation for booster vaccines for those in the 12 to 15 year old cohort, he said, adding that the National Immunisation Advisory Committee (Niac) is currently examining the issue.“There’s a lot to weigh up there so we’ll wait to hear back from them. I think we would expect something certainly in the next two to three weeks, I think we’d expect a recommendation from them either way on this.”On the remaining restrictions in schools, Dr Glynn said public health officials are reviewing evidence about mask-wearing for primary schools and will make a recommendation on it later this month.Asked about the difference between pubs and schools, Dr Glynn said a “key part” of the rationale is to give all children in primary schools an opportunity to be vaccinated. title: a 37 acre central bank site near m50 set to be designated for social housing
story: The currency centre in Sandyford retains the facility to mint euro coin at the siteA large tract of Central Bank lands near the M50 motorway in south Dublin is set to be designated for social and affordable housing as the bank reviews the future of its high-security currency centre in Sandyford.The 37-acre site, home of the national mint for decades, is in the sights of the Land Development Agency (LDA) as it prepares to submit a statutory list to the Government of public lands suitable for housing. The agency, which was set up to amass and develop State property for housing, aims to build 8,000 new dwellings around the State over the next five years. Members of Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council have voted to provide residential and open space zoning on the Central Bank site, rejecting the proposal of planners in the council’s draft development plan to seek zoning for economic use. The council aims to adopt the 2022-2028 development plan next month. “These lands should provide local affordable homes for families in the Dundrum, Stillorgan, Sandyford areas,” said Fine Gael councillor Barry Saul. “People who grew up in the locality should be afforded the ability to purchase a new affordable home in their locality.”The Central Bank is listed as a relevant public body with relevant public land in the law underpinning the LDA. The bank is on a list of bodies whose lands must be built out with 100 per cent social and affordable housing if they come under LDA control, thereby limiting the price at which such property would transfer to the agency. This has led to some disquiet behind the scenes. Certain figures in the Central Bank have argued privately that the institution should not be compelled to sell land for less than the market rate, saying such a move would infringe its independence of the Government. The bank has ruled out a move in the short-term, saying in a statement that the timeframe would be “at least five to seven years” if change is recommended. “We continue to conduct a strategic review into the future of the currency centre in Sandyford,” it said. “If that strategic review recommends moving to another location, the Central Bank of Ireland will have due regard to the contents of the Land Development Agency Act and any planning regulations that are in place.”The bank has been in Sandyford for more than 40 years. The currency centre is a storage and distribution facility for bulk cash services, necessitating permanent Defence Forces protection and extensive surveillance. It stopped printing banknotes there in 2019 as euro notes are imported, but retains the facility to mint euro coin at the site.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: omicron subvariant ba 2 has potential to replace original globally says who
story: There appears to be no difference in disease severity in new BA.2 subvariant. Photograph: iStock The emerging BA.2 form of the Omicron coronavirus variant does not seem to be any more severe than the original BA.1 form, an official of the World Health Organization said on Tuesday.Vaccines also continue to provide similar protection against the different forms of Omicron, said Dr Boris Pavlin of the WHO’s Covid-19 Response Team.The comments come as the BA.2 subvariant begins to replace Omicron’s more common “original” BA.1 subvariant in countries such as Denmark.Based on data from Denmark, the first country where BA.2 overtook BA.1, there appears to be no difference in disease severity, although BA.2 has the potential to replace BA.1 globally, Dr Pavlin added.“Looking at other countries where BA.2 is now overtaking, we’re not seeing any higher bumps in hospitalisation than expected,” he said.BA.2 is more transmissible than the more common BA.1 and able to infect vaccinated people, according to a Danish study which analysed coronavirus infections in more than 8,500 Danish households between December and January.The subvariant is already becoming dominant in the Philippines, Nepal, Qatar, India and Denmark, Dr Pavlin said.He added: “Vaccination is profoundly protective against severe disease, including for Omicron. BA.2 is rapidly replacing BA.1. Its impact is unlikely to be substantial, although more data are needed.” –ReutersStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: brexit poots to decide shortly on unilateral action to halt checks at ni ports
story: Edwin Poots claims that recent court rulings mean the Executive must give its approval for the checks to continue. Other parties have called the move a stunt. Photograph: Liam McBurneyPANorthern Ireland’s Minister of Agriculture has warned he will decide “shortly” whether to take unilateral action to halt post-Brexit checks at the North’s ports.Edwin Poots told BBC Radio Ulster he had sought legal advice after he attempted to bring a paper to the Northern Executive seeking approval for the checks on agri-food products.The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Assembly member said he expected to receive the advice of senior counsel “imminently” and would make a decision after he considers the advice.“If the advice leads me to a conclusion that the staff need to have the legal basis to operate there, which stems from having Executive approval, then I’ll have to act on that,” he said.He also warned that the DUP could take action soon to withdraw its ministers from Stormont over the lack of progress on the Northern Ireland protocol.“What we have currently is entirely unacceptable and if people think that is something that we’re just going to allow to grind on and on and on then that’s not going to happen,” he said.“The European Union negotiators have been dragging their feet and there’s a consequence for that and that consequence is coming down the line, and it’s coming down the line very, very fast.“This situation cannot go on much longer. If we’re not into days, then it’s weeks, but my suspicion is it’s more like days.”The DUP and other unionist parties are opposed to the Northern Ireland protocol, the part of the Brexit withdrawal agreement that avoided a hard Border on the island of Ireland by creating a customs and regulatory border in the Irish Sea.They claim it is creating economic hardship and has undermined the North’s constitutional position as an integral part of the UK by placing a barrier between it and Britain.Mr Poots’s attempt to seek a vote on the checks last week was part of his party’s broader campaign against the protocol.The DUP has repeatedly threatened to withdraw its ministers from the Stormont Executive – potentially leading to the collapse of the power-sharing institutions – if sufficient changes are not made to the protocol.He claims that recent court rulings mean the Executive must give its approval for the checks to continue.The move was criticised as a stunt by other parties, who maintain the Executive has already agreed his department is responsible for carrying out the checks and he does not have the authority to halt them as they are a requirement of the Brexit withdrawal agreement, an international agreement.Had his paper been discussed at the Executive, under Stormont rules the DUP could have used its veto to block approval for the checks.However, Sinn Féin used its veto to prevent it making it on to the agenda.Political careerMeanwhile, Mr Poots said on Wednesday his political demise has “not just happened quite yet” after he failed to secure the nomination to stand as his party’s candidate in South Down in the Assembly elections, which are due in May.The decision to select Diane Forsythe has to be ratified by the party’s Executive.Mr Poots is one of two DUP MLAs in Lagan Valley – the other is the First Minister Paul Givan – while the party leader Jeffrey Donaldson – currently the constituency’s MP – is to seek election to the Assembly there in May.“Everything I have done I have been doing in the interests of the party,” he said. title: hormone replacement therapy sold counter first time
story: Hormone replacement therapy is to be made available over the counter for the first time, watchdogs are poised to announce.Until now, women have only been able to access the medication after consultation with a GP or specialist.Every year, around 1.5 million women experience troubling post-menopausal symptoms including hot flushes, night sweats, sleep disturbance and emotional problems. Of those, around 150,000 are prescribed HRT in the form of tablets, gels, creams or patches.The  can disclose that watchdogs are set to propose a reclassification of the medication so women are able to access it in a pharmacy without a prescription.It follows changes last summer that saw the contraceptive pill sold over the counter following a relaxation of rules by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency.It also comes after a long campaign to improve access to HRT and reduce the cost for women who receive it on prescription.In October, ministers announced that costs would be cut by up to £200 a year after the Government backed a campaign championed by celebrities including Penny Lancaster and Davina McCall. Under that change, costs of up to £19 per month can be replaced by one annual prescription for the same cost.The latest proposal aims to improve convenience so that women are able to access HRT more easily, without needing a GP appointment. But it follows years of debate over the risks and benefits of HRT, which has been linked to an increased risk of breast cancer.Haitham Hamoda, the chairman of the British Menopause Society, said: Improving access to HRT is a good thing, but it is really important that women can access all the help and advice they need.It's great that there is so much conversation about menopause now, and people are far more open about it. But we don't want this to come down to a question of self-diagnosis – it's really important that those thinking about starting HRT get the right information.Some pharmacists already employ trained prescribers who are able to issue medicines on prescription. The latest changes may still require a consultation with a pharmacist, as is the case when the contraceptive pill is purchased over the counter.The number of women taking HRT therapy fell dramatically after a major 2002 study linked it to an increased risk of breast cancer. Since then, evidence has been conflicting.In 2015, NHS watchdogs said far more help should be offered to those suffering debilitating night sweats and hot flushes. Experts from the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence suggested at least twice as many women could benefit from HRT as were actually on it, saying far too many had been left in unbearable misery.In 2019, a Lancet review said the therapy raised the risks of breast cancer by one third. It found that while the risk of breast cancer was 6.3 per cent for women aged between 50 and 69 who have not taken HRT, it rises to 8.3 per cent for those on the most common combination of HRT.The medication works by boosting levels of the hormones oestrogen and progesterone, which are lower among women during the menopausal period.  Last year, a study found that taking hormone replacement therapy during the menopause does not increase the risk of dementia. However, staying on HRT long term was linked to a slight increase in the risk of Alzheimer's.The changes will mean pharmaceutical manufacturers can apply for reclassification of their products, allowing over-the-counter sale under the supervision of a qualified pharmacist.  They come as ministers prepare to extend rules that allow abortion pills to be taken at home. Since the start of the Covid pandemic, home abortions have been allowed in the first 10 weeks of pregnancy in legislation due to expire at the end of next month. But the  understands that period will now be extended in a move likely to anger anti-abortion groups and some MPs.Clare Murphy, the chief executive of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, said: Improving access to HRT as well as abortion and contraception is really important for women, so this is extremely welcome news.A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: We understand that, for some women, menopause symptoms can have a significant impact on their quality of life, and we are committed to improving the care and support they receive.That's why we're developing the first ever government-led Women's Health Strategy, informed by women's lived experience. Menopause, including improving access to Hormone Replacement Therapy, will be a priority under the strategy.More from NewsWatch PMQs live: Speculation mounts another Tory will join Tobias Ellwood and call for Boris Johnson to quitUkraine crisis latest: US offers Russia chance to inspect for Tomahawk missiles in Eastern EuropeHow the ‘Partygate’ scandal has sent Boris Johnson’s approval rating plummeting&#39Indiana Jones of the art world&#39 returns statue to France 50 years after heistDuchess of Cambridge ready to tackle her next role ... as patron of England rugby boardsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: mi6 chiefs wordle outburst sparks five letter response
story: The head of MI6 has revealed his annoyance at puzzle game Wordle spoilers being revealed as his outburst sparked a playful spat between C and GCHQ.Richard Moore, the chief of MI6, tweeted Wednesday that he was “thinking” of unfollowing accounts on the social media site that revealed the day’s answer in the online game.His comment prompted the official Twitter account of GCHQ to tweet a mocked-up graphic of the game with the word ‘sorry’ on it in response.The playful exchange between the head of the UK’s foreign intelligence agency and its digital spy body comes as Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited the Ukraine over mounting concerns of a possible Russian invasion.In the midst of the crisis, the head of MI6 indicated this morning that he is enjoying playing the hit game, which sees people given six attempts to guess a five letter word.Players are then given clues about which letters they got right and if they were in the right place to help them solve the puzzle.The game, which only releases one new word a day, has become an internet sensation with celebrities such as TV author and presenter Richard Osman and BBC anchor Dan Walker among its fans.Expressing his frustration at those who reveal the answer before people are able to solve it themselves, Mr Moore tweeted: “Thinking of unfollowing those who post their #Wordle results…”He then posted the GCHQ response to his feed.The exchange prompted other users on Twitter to offer Mr Moore advice on how to avoid seeing the Wordle answer online, such as removing tweets with it from his feed.Another user added: “I would hope you would know their results before they post them - kind of the point of your role.”Meanwhile, the agency will be busy monitoring the build-up and movements of around 100,000 Russian troops on the border with Ukraine.Mr Johnson flew out to Kyiv yesterday in show of support to Ukrainian president  Volodymyr Zelensky, as the UK supplies the Eastern European nation with weapons ahead of any escalation in the conflict.More from NewsWatch PMQs live: Speculation mounts another Tory will join Tobias Ellwood and call for Boris Johnson to quitUkraine crisis latest: US offers Russia chance to inspect for Tomahawk missiles in Eastern EuropeHow the ‘Partygate’ scandal has sent Boris Johnson’s approval rating plummeting&#39Indiana Jones of the art world&#39 returns statue to France 50 years after heistDuchess of Cambridge ready to tackle her next role ... as patron of England rugby boardsMajority of public think Boris Johnson should resign over alleged Downing Street partiesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: wordle won world
story: Some people are calling it the biggest sellout since Nick Clegg took the Liberal Democrats into coalition with the Conservatives 12 years ago. Wordle, the online word puzzle turned sleeper viral hit, has been bought by the New York Times for a seven-figure sum, just weeks after its creator Josh Wardle said: “I think people kind of appreciate that there’s this thing online that’s just fun. It’s not trying to do anything shady with your data or your eyeballs.”It’s hard to blame Wardle, a British software engineer from near Abergavenny but based in Brooklyn, or wish him anything other than good luck. Knowing his partner loved word games, Wardle created the guessing game for her, naming it Wordle as a play on his own surname. But once it caught on in his family’s WhatsApp group he released it to the rest of the world in October last year and its popularity snowballed beyond his wildest dreams. How many of us, having – as he did – created the game as a fun challenge for his partner, would turn down more than a million bucks? The gratitude of strangers doesn’t pay the bills. Besides, the experience of going from unknown to internet stardom must be incredibly discombobulating. “I’d be lying if I said this hasn’t been a little overwhelming,” he said.But by the same token it’s difficult to escape the feeling that something pure and innocent has been broken. Since it first appeared last October, Wordle has been free from advertising and subscription alike, uncluttered by adverts or notifications. Wardle himself was endearingly honest about his lack of greed. “I don’t have to charge people money for this and ideally would like to keep it that way,” he said last month. “The business side of things is not super interesting to me at all, and I can’t imagine anyone paying… I’m just kind of suspicious of apps and games that want your endless attention. I worked in Silicon Valley. I know why they do that. I kind of deliberately did what you’re not meant to do if growth is your goal. I think people have an appetite for things that transparently don’t want anything from you.”Jonathan Knight, general manager of the New York Times’ games ision, says Wordle “has done what so few games have done: it has captured our collective imagination.” He’s right about that. I’m one of the millions – at least two million and counting, up from 90 players in November and 300,000 at the beginning of January – who play it every day, sometimes clicking on the homepage at exactly midnight when a new puzzle goes live.The rules are simple: you have six attempts to guess a five-letter word. If you guess the right letter in the right place that letter turns green, the right letter in the wrong place turns yellow, and a wrong letter stays grey. I have good-natured competitions going on with my wife and friends, though the essential benevolence (at least from my end) is regularly tested by the fact that it takes me noticeably more attempts than it does them. I maintain that this is because I’m a writer and therefore think of many more different words than they do. Their replies provide me with yet more possible answers for future puzzles: if not for Wordle itself, then for its smutty parody Lewdle.There are many reasons for the game’s success. It’s an intellectual exercise, and we like to feel clever. It’s hard, but not too hard: the answer is always an obvious one in retrospect (even if British players were upset the other day when the chosen word was FAVOR, spelt the American way). “I feel smart when I get a Wordle, even though I made the game,” Wardle says. “It’s about the journey, especially on days where I’m really stumped and have to think about it. It’s sufficiently hard to enable me to hit a sense of accomplishment that feels good.” We can try to work out which words are best to start with (at least two vowels and probably an ‘S’ too). We have to think not just of inidual letters but of combinations too: ‘r’ is often a good second letter after a hard consonant such as ‘p’ or ‘t’.Social media and messaging services have made results easy to share, and the grid Wardle has designed for this is perfect: it shows your results without giving away the answers. In the progress from one colourful line to the next is a litany of decisions, guesses, failures and triumphs. The mixture of isolation and connectivity which these grids represent is a perfect reflection of pandemic times. “I get emails from people who say things like ‘Hey, we can’t see our parents due to Covid at the moment but we share our Wordle results each day’,” Wardle says. “During this weird time it’s a way for people to connect in a low-effort, low-friction way.”“The fact that we are all trying to solve the same puzzle brings us together,” says psychologist Lee Chambers. “There’s both a sense of community in terms of ‘How difficult did people find it this time?’ and a competitive angle in terms of ‘How well did I stack up in finding this word compared to everyone else?’’’Most of all, Wordle’s success has been down to the fact that there’s only one a day. We live in an age not just of more, more, more but also of now, now, now: everything we want is available instantly in its entirety. TV shows, films, books, games: they’re all just a click away. But Wordle is different. There’s no cache of old games, no easy store of upcoming ones (yes, computer scientists have broken the source code and you can find websites where all future answers are listed, but where’s the fun in that?) There’s just today’s game, nothing else. It harks back to the days of vinyl records and analogue TV, of 90-minute TDK cassettes and the Radio 1 charts on Sunday afternoon: simpler times in a less atomised society. “The internet is in a really bad place at the moment, but this is great because it’s not doing all those nasty things,” says Adam Procter, who leads the computer game design course at Southampton University.Wordle is not, it has to be said, especially original: there are shades both of the TV show Lingo and the 1970s peg-and-board game Mastermind, which had on the lid a bearded man and a woman in white staring at the camera with disturbing intensity. But very few games can claim to have a single inventor: number puzzles, for example, began in French newspapers in the late 19th century, whereas Sudoku’s popularity in the West today is a joint effort between American puzzle constructor Howard Garns (whose grids ran in magazines from 1979) and Hong Kong judge Wayne Gould, who developed a computer programme capable of rapidly producing multiple unique puzzles.Wordle’s success also points to a wider social trend: we are obsessed with puzzles. No pub is complete without a quiz, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? has entered the national psyche, Mastermind is still going 50 years after its first broadcast and University Challenge now gets former alumni back for Christmas spin-offs to go alongside the main franchise. GCHQ advertises for codebreakers and puzzle solvers. Crime fiction, which is all about using clues to solve mysteries, remains hugely popular both in bookstores and on TV: before Richard Osman’s multi-million-selling Thursday Murder Club series came Dan Brown, whose Angels and Demons and The Da Vinci Code were essentially coded treasure hunts wrapped up in thriller clothes. Newspapers carry entire supplements of Sudoku grids, crosswords and other puzzles. Interestingly, the modern crossword also dates from troubled times, beginning in American newspapers in 1913, just before World War I. Crosswords became ever more popular during the Great Depression as a distraction from people’s troubles, and only one newspaper held out against including one until after Pearl Harbor – the same one that has just bought Wordle.The New York Times has pledged that Wordle will “be free to play for new and existing players, and no changes will be made to its gameplay,” at least for the time being. And if the game remains essentially the same, the logical and intellectual challenges it poses should also be undimmed. But those are only part of what makes, or perhaps made, Wordle so special. It was something we felt belonged to us all, unmonetised and unexploited, and now it belongs to a £5bn corporation. If ever there was a moral for our times – or perhaps a MORAL for our TIMES, get it in six tries or fewer – it is this.More from NewsWatch PMQs live: Speculation mounts another Tory will join Tobias Ellwood and call for Boris Johnson to quitUkraine crisis latest: US offers Russia chance to inspect for Tomahawk missiles in Eastern EuropeHow the ‘Partygate’ scandal has sent Boris Johnson’s approval rating plummeting&#39Indiana Jones of the art world&#39 returns statue to France 50 years after heistDuchess of Cambridge ready to tackle her next role ... as patron of England rugby boardsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: brits cant afford lose 2000
story: Brits cant afford to lose £, more every year without help from governmentThe Cabinet Ministers increasing taxes on incomes through National Insurance or failing to cool rising prices – particularly soaring fuel bills – are a major part of the problemBoris Johnson and the Conservative Party only pretend they support people Image: UK PARLIAMENT AFP via Getty ImagopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Feb |comments Slashing the living standards of families who are already feeling the squeeze could trigger a ferocious backlash against the Conservatives and Boris Johnson.Households simply cannot lose nearly £, in spending power without feeling intense pain or plunging into debt. The Cabinet Ministers increasing taxes on incomes through National Insurance or failing to cool rising prices – particularly soaring fuel bills – are a major part of the problem. One of the fundamental iding lines in politics is whose side a party is on. Opinion polls suggest voters are recognising the Conservatives are tightening family budgets callously whereas Labour is proposing fully-costed policies to put extra money into pay packets and slow price hikes. Working people deserve better from a government and political party which only pretends it is on their side, levelling down their living standards while ly claiming to want to level up those it disadvantaged for years.  What a waste We are learning how the Conservatives cannot be trusted with taxpayers’ money as they admitted to £.billion losses on Covid PPE contracts worth £.bn. Every piece of unusable, unsuitable and overpriced item is charged to the British public and the colossal waste of our money by the Government is indefensible. Add other unacceptable bills such as the £.bn in loans and financial support written off as Covid fraud and the total tops £bn before other areas are counted – enough to cancel a year’s National Insurance rises or suspend BBC licence fees for nearly four years. Joker hurts UK Russian mockery of Boris Johnson’s visit to Ukraine would normally be dismissed as Putin propaganda. Yet the truth for Britain is that our Prime Minister is an international joke and our country is further diminished every day that the lying charlatan survives in Downing Street. title: dominic cummings has been told
story: Dominic Cummings has been told there are photos of party in Boris Johnsons flatThe PMs former top advisor claims there are photos of Boris Johnson at events that are under investigation by police - and says he has been told that there are photos of a party in his Downing Street flat Image: Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Feb |commentsDominic Cummings has been told there are photographs of a party in Boris Johnsonaposs Downing Street flat - and more pictures which will incriminate the Prime Minister.The Prime Ministeraposs former chief aide has alleged there are photographs of Boris Johnson at reported gatherings under investigation by police. In a question and answer session on his paid-for blog, Mr Cummings was askedthere were photos that would incriminate the Prime Minister.He said: Yes there are photos of the PM at parties under investigation. Ive spoken to people who say theyve seen photos of parties in the flat. He also claimed he had spoken to people who were in No  on November  , when there was an alleged gathering in Mr Johnsonaposs Downing Street flat.  He said: Ive talked to people who were in no on   who cd hear the party in no after Iaposd left - the press office is below the flat. If cops talk to people there that night, therell be witnsesseswho say aposwe could all hear a party with abba playingapos. He accused the PM of lying and added: This could blow up terminally for himlies to the cops but he wont be able to help himself other than say aposi dont rememberapos which is his default when he senses danger.Mr Cummings said the chances of Foreign Secretary Liz Truss becoming Tory leader are probably being overrated.The Prime Ministeraposs former top aide said the fact that MPs are heavily influenced by polls would obviously benefitSunak in any future leadership race, and said Mr Sunak pro-Brexit stance would also help him. He said Ms Truss was little known and had said a lot of stuff that will not be popular with members  when they hear it. If she gets to the last , the combination of her support for Remain and her record will be big problems for her. Her chances are probably being overrated, he said.He said he thought Levelling Up Secretary Michael Gove probably will run again, while on Tory MP Tom Tugendhat, he said: He has never been in Cabinet and it is hard to imagine Tory MPs promoting someone straight to the top job who has not been in Cabinet.He said: RS is obviously the front runner cos heaposs way ahead in the polls and unlike Truss Hunt TT was pro-Brexit. His team conceived and executed furlough in very tough circumstances, and which was one of most popular things a politician has done in a very long time. That will be a big strength when the contest comes. He went on to tell Tory MPs there was no excuse for self-delusions about Boris Johnson. At this point the blame lies mostly with the Tory MPs, he wrote. Heaposs obviously totally unfit for the job and every day heaposs left their moral authority drops another notch. But he added: Thereaposs lots of blame to go around beyond them, including people in no who have also shown a distinct lack of moral courage... On Sue Gray limited report, he said: So far as I know sheaposs done a professional job in appalling circumstances. news politics rishi-sunak-packed-parliament-family-"Rishi Sunak sits behind Johnson as PM reacts to Sue Gray reportByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsRishi Sunak sat in a packed House of Commons on Monday despite a close family member testing positive for Covid, the Mirror can reveal.The Chancellor nestled between Boris Johnson and Home Secretary Priti Patel as the PM delivered his statement on Downing Street lockdown parties.He appeared despite official guidance strongly advising people to limit close contact with otherssomebody in their household tested positive.Mr Sunakaposs actions are in contrast to those of the PM, who cancelled official engagements and holed up in Downing Street when his daughter caught Covid last month. Treasury insiders denied that Mr Johnson had set a precedent that other ministers should follow.  They said Mr Sunak had felt it was important to be visible and supportive of the Government on the day Sue Gray published an update of her report. The Chancellor later attended a crowded meeting of the Toriesapos backbench  committee in a show of solidarity with his beleaguered boss. And he led Treasury questions in the House of Commons chamber on Tuesday.  Mr Sunak, who was one of the only ministers wearing a facemask on the frontbench, tested negative before the Commons statement.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss, sitting on Ms Patelaposs other side, later tested positive for Covid and was forced to miss her trip to the Ukraine with the PM. The legal requirement to stay at homeyou have a positive case in your household is no longer in place.But official NHS guidance still “strongly advises” people to limit close contact with others in crowded spaces and work from homepossible.It states that they should limit close contact with other people outside your household, especially in crowded, enclosed or poorly ventilated spaces. The advice adds that people should work from homeyou are able to and wear a face-covering in crowded places. A spokesman for Mr Sunak said: The Chancellor has followed the legal requirements to the letter. “He has taken daily lateral flow tests and has limited his social contact where possible, whilst also ensuring that he is able to continue to conduct important Government and Parliamentary business as the public would expect.  Just last month, No  announced Mr Johnson was unlikely to be seen in public for a week after a member of his immediate family, later revealed to be baby Romy, tested positive for Covid. The PMaposs official spokesman said he would heed official guidance to limit outside contacts as much as possible for seven days after the test. “In line with the guidance, he’s reducing contact, he told reporters. He’ll be working from No , doing daily tests and limiting contact with others both outside No  and indeed inside No  as well, having limited contact with others in the building, and conducting meetings online.” However, Mr Johnson faced accusations he was hiding behind the illness, as it came while he faced intense scrutiny over his attendance at a BYOB garden party in No  during lockdown. The PM cancelled a visit to a vaccination centre in Lancashire, where he would have faced tough media questions, while a Downing Street press conference was also axed. title: the tory party is over
story: What the Tories think of Boris Johnson is irrelevant. The PM will soon be out on his earThe Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds about whether this is survivable, says Fleet Street Fox. It isnt Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWell. The Prime Minister is under direct criminal investigation. The evidence of his alleged crimes are being kept hidden from him for fear of interference.And with war brewing on Europeaposs eastern flank, the PM told the enemy he didnapost have time to ring, because he had too much arse-covering to do.The Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds, not about whether this is acceptable, but whether itaposs survivable. And like every victim, it has yet to realisethataposs the question, then itaposs time to go.  Yesterday, a report he resisted ordering was not published. Instead, there was an aposupdateapos on the alleged criminality of his office, his staff, and his personal residence, and the PM greeted it in the same way he has every Mirror front page, ITV broadcast, and BBC breaking news update since late November: a burst of surprise and contrition with a half-le of . seconds, decaying into toxic belligerence that will linger in the bone for a thousand years. Events for which there was not enough evidence to merit an investigation by the politan Police had, in the space of a month, uncovered  witnesses,  photographs, and  pieces of paper.Despite the insufficient evidence,  out of  parties, on  dates, have met the evidential threshold for an investigation, on the grounds that those involved knew they were against the rules, there was no reasonable justication for them, and not looking into it would end Cressida Dickaposs career quicker than sending the riot squad into a candlelit vigil.One of them is an alleged gathering in the Downing Street flat on November , , which Mrs Johnsonaposs personal spokeswoman has repeatedly insisted is total nonsense, but about which there seems to be enough evidence to merit weeks of attention by an entire squad of coppers.  While the -page report has been subbed down to just , it contains all the facts needed to decide the PMaposs future. Extensive, substantive, factual information is now available, wrote Sue Gray. There were failures of leadership and judgement. There was excessive consumption of alcohol. There was no way for those working in government to stop it breaking the law. There was a serious failure to observe, not just the standards expected of those working at the heart of government, but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.The killer line is in paragraph . The excuse of long hours worked in the pandemic, in a building that could not be entirely Covid-secure, was destroyed. Those challenges... also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health... criminal sanctions were applied to many... the hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Governmentaposs regulations and guidance are known only too well. Every citizen has been impacted by the pandemic. One of them is Leshie Chandrapala. Her dad drove a bus. He died of Covid, and Leshie was not allowed to be with him as he lay in a coma in ICU. She believes he died because he didnapost get PPE at work, but the government hasnapost even written a letter of condolence to her family. A fortnight after he died, and while she grieved, they threw the BYO booze Downing Street garden party. The PMaposs response to the report was to say sorry for the way itaposs been handled, not sorry for doing it. And he has a solution. I know what the issue is, he declared. I get it, and I will fix it! He says he is taking personal charge, and setting up the Office of the Prime Minister. So who was in charge of his office for the past three years  Where is the drunken boozehound who careered around Downing Street Friday night drinkathons, encouraging staffers to let off steam with a long chug on the vodka bottle  Who allowed the culture of recklessness and lawlessness, at the heart of a government that was criminalising the same sins in others  Which leader has led his party to a disgrace worse than Windrush or Grenfell or Orgreave Bring me his head! bellows Boris from the Despatch Box. I will slay this beast, the same way that I would have slain Jimmy Savile,only I didnapost think that investigating historical sex abuse was money spaffed up the wall!Other things he has taken personal control of include Brexit, social care, test and trace, the energy crisis, the ministerial code of conduct, the saving of Owen Paterson, and funding for his gold wallpaper. The fact he took personal control of the vaccines may have something to do with the fact that  million people donapost want them. How many times has he taken charge, only for things to spin out of control  How many times has he shaken up the civil service, only to be rattled himself  Read more The nation is now watching the Conservative Party the same way as the rest of the street watches a victim get out of the police car, andto their abuser. They drag with them a whole country into this deranged, gnarled, unhappy misgovernment, back to the man who wonapost promise to publish the full truth in the House of Commons, where he might be held in contempthe failed to, but will promise it in the bar, to the MPs he has lied to for years, and who have been brainwashed into thinking such a promise is a concession rather than a repetition.Meanwhile the PM only appears in public when the public can be kept away from him. Abba tribute bands are raising their prices for satin satire. Andyou want a three-word slogan to describe where we are, it is simply: another fine mess. The PM or his we may get a fixed penalty notice pictures may or may not emerge. He may be out on his ear, or he may convince enough MPs to give him one more go. Itaposs irrelevant, because the fallout of this radioactive scandal will last to the ballot box and beyond it reaches into homes and hearts, to the guts and spines of millions to whom the words aposToryapos and aposPartyapos are now as repugnant as the fact that people like Leshie had their pain doubled and then dismissed by a man whose charm has long since been spent. The Tories got drunk on power, picked a man who can be fooled by a cake, and then dithered about whether to let him keep hurting the rest of us. They cannot see what the rest of us can: their party is over. title: catcalling unacceptable needs taken seriously
story: Catcalling is unacceptable - it needs to be taken seriously once and for allBradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcallingImage: Getty Images AlloyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Feb |commentsIt probably seems like a small thing, at best. At worst, a waste of time and resources. It’s not though. It’s important. A tiny triumph. A baby step in the right direction. Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – “targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.” Last week they stopped a van after the occupant yelled at some women who turned out to be plain-clothed police officers. Oh to have seen his face. He was reported for a breach of the Public Spaces Protection Order and is likely to be issued with a £ fine or taken to court, which is another way of saying that he was left in no doubt that THIS IS NOT OK. That’s apparently what men need to be told, reminded of, in no uncertain terms, so they’re one hundred per cent clear. No, it’s not just a bit of harmless fun that we need to lighten up about. It’s horrendous. Scary. Humiliating.  Maybe this concept is confusing because we’re living in an age of sharing, honesty, and talking about everything. Mostly that’s great, but somewhere within this, a simple truth has got lost. Sometimes, it’s good NOT to talk. Sometimes, you need to shut the hell up. Perhaps we need a massive advertising campaign, public service announcement telly commercials and posters everywhere to clearly inform everyone once and for all: Stop telling women what you think of their bodies. Especially when they haven’t asked, which is pretty much always. There are no Thought Police – anyone is free to think whatever they like. The opinions inside someone’s head can’t hurt anyone . The problem comes when they’re broadcast out loud to the woman you’re thinking them about, be it on the street, online, or on a radio show, like that fool who talked about Strictly’s Tilly Ramsay. What you think of the woman’s body is irrelevant, by the way. Evenyou believe it’s a compliment, still keep it to yourself. Of course there are exceptions to the rule, but most women do not feel flattered and delighted when a stranger gives them positive feedback about a body part. We feel embarrassed, and frightened. And we’re taught to ignore this behaviour – apart from in Bradford, it’s up to us to deal with it ourselves – to put our heads down, walk quicker, in case the situation escalates.We’re luckywe are only verbally harassed. Even online, where the threat of physical violence is removed, these kind of comments are dangerous, and unacceptable. They perpetuate the belief that women’s appearances are fair game for discussion and debate. That our bodies are anyone’s business but our own. They also ensure that the practice of speaking about women in this way seeps down to future generations, continuing the cycle. It has to stop. As the fight to make our streets safer for women goes on, catcalling being taken seriously in one city in the UK is just a drop in the ocean. But at least it’s a start. Maybe those TV ads aren’t a bad idea – and it’s obvious what music they should be set to. Ronan Keating, You Say It Best, When You Say Nothing At All. title: couple lose 50000 after cowboy
story: Couple lose £, after cowboy builder walks off saying he doesnt the need stressJames Bradshaw said his family were left living on a building site in Wolverhampton after their builder walked off the job and a survey later showed all his work needed to be demolishedThe house was left with a half-finished extension after the builder walked off the job, saying he didnt need the stress Image: Kennedy News and MediaByRebecca CooleyJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A devastated couple say they have lost their £, le savings and been left living on a building site thanks to a cowboy builderaposs half-finished extension which then had to be demolished. James Bradshaw, , says the builder, who heaposd hired to add a two-storey extension to their house, would only work five-hour days and when confronted about his shoddy workmanship brazenly quit saying he didnapost want the stress .The couple agreed to pay almost £, to the builder, who came recommended by a family friend, for an extension to accommodate their growing family, a job that was supposed to be completed by August . But after months of issues and delays the builder vanished in September, leaving James and his family £, out of pocket and living on a building site. The -year-old says he has since had a surveyor assess the work that had been done, who concluded that it needed to be completely demolished and restarted due to structural issues. When James contacted a solicitor he was advised not to bother taking the builder to court as he wonapost see a penny of his hard-earned savings again - evenhe wins the case.  The sales director has now shared photos of the mess heaposs been left with in a bid to warn other conscientious and decent peopleapos not to fall victim to cowboy builders. James, from Wolverhampton, said: The reason we were having the extension done is because weaposve had a daughter and we have three children living with us already - my son and my fianceaposs two children. We were having the extension done to create two extra bedrooms and to extend the kitchen and dining room to have a bit more space for the kids. It was shocking from day one. He never did a full week, heaposd only turn up two to three times a weekat all and heaposd turn up at :am and leave at pm. Every time the building inspector came to review the work heaposd done it kept getting failed so he had to redo lots of it. Eventually I said to him aposyou need to come in for a meeting because this just isnapost good enoughapos. As he walked through the door he said aposIaposm going to give you your money back and you can get someone  to complete it because I canapost get it done and I donapost want the stress anymoreapos. He only offered us £, back and I just said aposyouaposre a joke and youaposll be hearing from our solicitoraposs. He left our house in the state itaposs in and we havenapost spoken to him since. Itaposs been a nightmare. Itaposs put a lot of strain on mine and my partneraposs le and caused a lot of devastation for our family. Weaposd been saving the money for about  years and weaposd got a loan to help as well which weaposre still paying back at the minute.  The two-storey extension was supposed to create two extra bedrooms and an extended kitchen and dining area within  weeks, for an agreed cost of £,. By the time of their final meeting in September - two months after the extension was supposed to be finished - there was only an incomplete single-storey and a plank of wood blocking where the back door used to be. The following month, an independent building survey confirmed that what was built was plagued with structural issues and needed to be completely demolished and restarted, despite the parents already forking out a whopping £,. The report found that the walls were out of square in numerous places and either had a cavity that was too wide or cavity ties that were too short. This means they werenapost fully tied in and didnapost provide full stability. It also noted that the entire structure was at risk of damp due to multiple issues, including mortar breaching the wall cavities, and aposlazy workmanshipapos was evident in the internal brickwork, where a broken brick aposlooked to have been jammed in placeapos. Overall the report concluded: Considering the overall condition of the build we would recommend that it is removed down to foundation level and the structure started again. Demolishing the work alone would cost an additional £. In light of this, James sought legal advice to try and claw back some of his hard-earned savings back to be able to recty the nightmare build.  But the dad says that his solicitor then delivered the devastating news that although he would definitely win in court he would never see a penny of the £, again because the builder could simply close the business down due to not having the funds to repay it. James said: I had a meeting with the solicitor and said aposdonapost tell me what I want to hear, tell me the honest truthapos. Her words were aposthe only person that wins in this is the solicitors because we get paid either way, itaposs going to cost you £, to £, to go to courtapos. She said aposyou will win in court but his solicitor will advise him to shut the company down because he hasnapost got the money to pay it back so you wonapost see a pennyapos.Two days after we received the court letter it came up on Facebook that the company was closed so I think heaposs already shut it down. Weaposve looked into his history a bit now as well and heaposs well known for opening companies and shutting them down - I think this is the fourth company heaposs done that with since . The family had new builders start at their home last week to demolish the unstable structure and restart the extension. But at a new estimated cost of £,, they can no longer afford to get much of the project done. The heartbroken dad hopes that by warning people about the dishonest and unreliable cowboy he fell victim to, he can help other families avoid the same fate. James said: Thereaposs nothing we can do now, we just have to bite the bullet that weaposre not going to get anything from it because the system doesnapost support this kind of thing. Weaposve got new builders in now but because weaposve wasted so much money we can only afford to get the shell done and weaposll have to do the inside stage by stage. The new quote to put right and finish it is £, because thereaposs been a huge increase in prices of building materials and labour as well as the extra work of demolishing it. story: Footballer took his own le after furlough compounded grief over mums deathJordan Tucker-Blanc, , was found dead at his home in Preston, Lancs., on November  by his dad Vincent - he was said to have been struggling with the death of his mum before he was furloughed in lockdownJordan Tucker-Blanc, , was found dead at his home in Preston, Lancs., by his dad Image: MEN MediaByAmy FentonAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb  A young footballer took his own le after he was furloughed during lockdown, an inquest heard.Jordan Tucker-Blanc, , was found dead at his home in Preston, Lancs., on November  by his dad Vincent.The young joiner had been furloughed during the coronavirus lockdown and this had compounded the grief he was suffering since the death of his mum, an inquest at Preston Coronersapos Court heard on Tuesday. Jordan was the captain of Longridge Town FC and had played for Liverpool FC and Blackburn Rovers during his youth career, LancsLive reported. He was described by friends and family during the inquest as very athletic.  His cousin told the hearing: He played football pretty much most of his le. He was at Liverpool, had trials at other clubs, played at Kendal Town. He was very athletic and loved football and always watched United. On November , the family found it out of the ordinary when Jordan had not been online for a while, the inquest heard. When his dad Vincent went round to his home he broke into the property but found his son dead inside.  Jordanaposs partner Eleanor Morgan revealed he had tried to get an appointment with his GP but had been unable to do so. Eleanor said: It was lockdown, he had lost his mum I thought he was doing okay until he became furloughed and was in the house on his own. It was Christmas time that we thought he looked like heaposd lost a lot of weight and didnapost seem himself. She said that he had attended several private counselling sessions and by May  he had seemed better. Eleanor said: He started to make things and he started to seem like Jordan again and then August or September he started to deteriorate and hid himself away. The coroneraposs court was filled with Jordanaposs pals and relatives who described him as someone who would help anybody. His cousin said: He was very, very outgoing and was always smiling. He loved his family loved everyone. Jordan was described as an accomplished joiner who could turn his hand to anything. Returning to the conclusion of suicide, the coroner described Jordanaposs death as a tragedy.After Jordanaposs death, Longridge Town posted a tribute on Twitter : “Everyone at Longridge Town FC is devastated to hear this morning that our former player Jordan Tucker has passed away.A great player and more importantly, a great lad. You will be sadly missed mate, RIP. With your mum now. Our thoughts and love go out to Vinny and Jordan’s family. *If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . story: Human remains found at nature reserve identied as man who disappeared  years agoJames Hodgkiss, from Bolton, was last seen was on August ,  with a black hand luggage bag - an extensive missing person investigation was launched a the time but he was never found-year-old James Hodgkiss, from Bolton, was seen was on August ,  Image: Greater Manchester Police   SWNSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsBones found on a nature reserve have been linked to a man who disappeared five years ago.James Hodgkiss, from Bolton, was reported missing in . Today Greater Manchester Police said the remains have been identied as his.Police were called to an area close to Future Park, Horwich, just before pm on January , following reports that bones had been discovered. The last time James, , was seen was on August , , when he was carrying a black hand luggage bag on Weston Street in Great Lever. An extensive missing person investigation was launched, but he was not located. An investigation is now ongoing to determine his cause of death.  Police said there are believed to be no suspicious circumstances surrounding his death and a report has been prepared for the coroner. His family are being supported by specialist officers. Detectives launched their investigation after the bones were discovered in a nature reserve and scoured the former Red Moss reserve after the grisly find. The reserve is a large area of marshland next to the Middlebrook Retail Park and is soon set to become a huge housing development.  Detective Chief Inspector Paul Rollinson, of GMPaposs Bolton district, said: Our thoughts go out to Jamesapos family and friends at this incredibly dficult time. We would now ask that their privacy be respected as they come to terms with this news. At the time of Jamesapos disappearance, an extensive missing person investigation was launched, with a number of searches carried out, as well as extensive financial, CCTV, and social media enquiries undertaken. story: Inside cop WhatsApp group where they joked about slapping your missus aboutIn one disgusting chat two officers talked about hitting their female partners, before calling women who had been victims of violence daft c**ts for getting murdered by menPolice officers sent vile messages Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb A vile set of WhatsApp groups and Facebook messenger chats saw police officers joke about slapping your missus about and calling them daft c**ts for getting murdered by their boyfriends.The string of messages were just examples of the so-called banter that was shared by officers, a report into behaviour at the Met has revealed.It showed the cops, who were not named, would exchange highly offensive racist, sexist and homophobic messages, while bullying and harassing colleagues. Most of the officers investigated were police constables and based at Charing Cross Station, according to the Independent Office for Police Conduct , leading to a number of recommendations in a report. In one disgusting chat two officers talk about hitting their female partners before blaming women in general for getting murdered by men.  It read: Officer : “I f**ing need to take my bird out, won’t see her until next Saturday. Then I have to work. Promised to take her out the Friday after. Making it up to her from when I backhanded her. Officer : “Grab her by the pussy.” Officer : “You ever slapped your missus  It makes them love you more. Seriously since I did that she won’t leave me alone. Now I know why these daft c**ts are getting murdered by their sp****c boyfriends. Knock a bird about and she will love you. Human nature. They are biologically programmed to like that shit.” Officer : “Lmao. Officer : “I’m right though.”  In another exchange a male officer sent a string of messages to a female colleague: “I would happily rape you.” “If I was single I would actually hate fuck you. “If I was single I would happily chloroform you.”One police officer was even referred to as “Mcrapey Raperson” in a WhatsApp exchange.The report noted that not all the police officers in the team shared these views, but they also found evidence that police officers were afraid of speaking out. Those who did were harassed, humiliated and excluded, with women told should “play the game or stay quiet”, or leave. The report also shows officers used homophobic language and shared a number of racist messages including references to African children, Somali people and Auschwitz that are too offensive to print. Responding to the report Home Secretary Priti Patel said: “Being a police officer is a privilege which has been abused by these sickening officers.“It has been clear for some time that there are problems with the culture of the politan Police, which is why last year I tasked the Angiolini Inquiry and the police inspectorate with investigating these deeply concerning issues. “I expect the politan Police and the Mayor of London to implement the recommendations of this report as soon as practically possible. The public rightly expects the behaviour of the police to be beyond reproach - standards must be raised.” Of the  officers investigated, two were dismissed for gross misconduct, two resigned and several face disciplinary action Nine are still serving in the force. story: Exclusive: Ive had no heating for month as cant afford bills and food - I share bed with kids to stay warmMum-of-two Beth Connock, who is a full-time carer for her disabled son, has to share a bed with her children to keep them warm after a hike in the price of oil left them without heatingThe family have been left without heating for a month Image: Beth ConnockByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb |commentsSingle mum Beth Connock can no longer afford to keep the house warm AND feed her two children after her heating bills soared by  per cent. The -year-old mum of two - who is a full-time carer to disabled son Tommy, aged  - has now lived without heating for more than a month.“Itaposs really upsetting because I feel like a failure of a mother. I can choose between keeping my house warm at the moment and feeding the kids. “And the kids need to be fed but they need to be warm, it’s quite upsetting. No one should have to choose between feeding or eating.” Beth is one of the . million UK householders whose heating is powered by oil as her home in the rural hamlet of Dartshill, Somerset does not have a mains gas supply.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her problem started as the cost to heat her family home, which she rents, rose sharply - from £ to £ for  litres, to fill less than half the tank.The cost of living crisis has left the mum, Tommy, five, and Gabby, three, forced to share a bed each night.They have a tiny electric heater to warm the bedroom they share, but in the evenings, they can see their breath in their living room when the temperature drops. Desperate to keep her children warm, Beth bundles them up in jumpers and scarves at home - but Tommy, who is autistic, struggles to wear the outfits. She says: “We’re wearing a lot of extra layers and having to sleep in the same bed to keep warm. “I shut the bedroom door to keep our body heat in but as soon as we got downstairs, it is freezing and we’re all shivering. “It’s a very old draughty cottage, I woke up the other morning around  am to find ice around the windowsill. “We’re wearing a lot more clothes, which means a lot more washing and a backlog of clothes as we wait days for things to dry. “It’s also a choice when it comes to hot water -the kids have a bath, I can’t have a shower as well.” She added: “I have no money and I’m worried about the kids getting ill because it is so cold. “February and March can be the coldest months so I needed to get something done quickly.” Tommy, aged five, is “very delayed” and has to wear specic clothes, meaning he doesn’t like wearing the extra layers.Beth is unable to work after becoming his full-time carer due to his severe epilepsy and the family rely on Universal Credit to get by.She previously tried to get a loan but was refused as she still owes around £ from the last loan she received. “I’ve tried everything. I even tried to get a grant in my local area but I heard nothing back,” the mum said. She also claims disability allowance to support him, who spent nine weeks in hospital in , suffering constant seizures. He has to wear a helmet to protect himselfhe falls, and mum Beth is on constant alert for his seizures. “Because of his epilepsy and autism, he is very delayed, and he doesn’t understand why we need to wear these extra clothes,” added Beth. “So trying to keep him warm it’s really dficult, he’s used to having heating and now we don’t have it. “It’s very frustrating for him.”  The desperate mum recently turned toGoFundMeto help cover the £ bill - where one kindhearted stranger donated £ anonymously.The hike in the price of oil comes amid a cost of living crisis with Beth’s rent recently rising by £ per month - a rise she will struggle to cover. Struggling Brits are bracing for further financial turmoil this spring - with tax rises, wage cuts and soaring bills set to batter household budgets further.The cost of living crisis could see families suffer a £, a year average hit, The Mirror exclusively revealed today - in a further blow to families such as Bethaposs.Low-income families are set to be the most affected by the crisis - with no spending they can cut back on. She said: “We scrape by every month, it’s dficult. With Universal Credit, I don’t knowthey’ll cover the rent increase. “As a single mum on benefits, £ is a lot of money. “Tommy’s school is about half an hour away so I do an hour-round journey every day to get him there. “It got to the point where I was desperate for heating and I just had to set up a GoFundMe page.” She plans to donate any excess to the Daisy Garland charity, that supported her family while Tommy was in the hospital.Donate to Beth’sGoFundMehere.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsOil pricesSingle mumEpilepsyAsperger’s syndromeEnergy bills" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Man dressed as creepy Squid Game character repeatedly seen walking through cityA man was spotted walking around Coventry dressed up as one of the red and black henchmen from the Netflix thriller Squid Game, leaving some locals wondering why he was in the outfitA man was spotted dressed up as a character from the Netflix thriller Squid GameByDanny ThompsonMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA man dressed in a creepy costume from the TV series Squid Game left onlookers stunned as he walked through a city centre. The fan was spotted in several dferent parts of Coventry, leaving locals confused about why he was wearing the red and black outfit.One theory is that he was on a stag do in the city and decided to dress up as one of the henchmen from the wildly popular Netflix thriller. Jaz Padam said he saw the man walking into the city centre while driving his car, CoventryLive reports.He said: He was walking towards town. Iaposd just drove past him, then took a picture as I was getting out of the car. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter I actually thought it was from the kids game Among Us, because I used to play with my children. Then it clicked it was from Squid Game. As he was heading towards the city centre I just thought he was probably heading to a stag do or something. The stag do theory would make sense, as dressing as comical or current characters is often part of the culture, but one or two things possibly rule it out. Firstly, the inidual was alone, and were he on a stag you might expect him to be with others in similar attire. Secondly, CoventryLive understands someone dressed in the same outfit has been spotted several times around the city on dferent days. For the uninitiated, Squid Game is a fictional drama series which sees contestants play a host of childrenaposs games in an attempt to be the overall winner and scoop a huge prize - but those who donapost win, die. It was released in September and quickly become wildly popular, particularly on social media where it created a huge amount of memes and gs. It became so ingrained in culture children have been known to play Squid Game on school playgrounds during breaks.The red outfit the inidual seen in Coventry is wearing is that of Squid Game aposguardsapos also known as Pink Soldiers or Masked Men, according to Squid-Game.fandom.The sighting comes after a man wearing a creepy clown costume was seen walking the streets of Speke, Merseyside, at night. The man was seen crouching behind bushes outside homes while dressed in the frightening costume which was complete with an oversized mask.A witness snapped a photo of the clown, the Liverpool Echo reported.His costume was made up of a black and white clown suit with a white neck ruff and a garish mask that featured a bright red nose, purple hair and giant teeth. A witness shared photos of the man crouched behind a bush and gesturing with his hand. The witness said: Itaposs thataposs time of the year again. Iaposve been out and about in Speke and I saw the clown out and about around Ganworth Road area. story: Man snaps photo of mystery silver object - which could be meteor speeding through skyThe man took the photo on East Park Road in North Evington at pm on Sunday - the same night that a fireball meteor was spotted blazing across the night sky in the UKA man saw a silver object in the sky which may have been a meteor Image: TwitterByCorey BedfordLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA man spotted a silver object flying through the sky at night - and it may have been a fireball meteor seen speeding across Europe. Snapped from a road in Leicester, the photo shows East Park Road in North Evington, a deep orange and almost red sunset. A silver line streaking through the middle of the sky can also be made out.The photo was taken at pm on Sunday, January , which just happened to be the same night that a fireball meteor was spotted blazing across the night sky in the UK, reports the Leicester Mercury. There were more than  reported sightings of the meteor on Saturday evening - however, most were slightly later in the day, at around pm. As well as in the UK, the meteor was also spotted across Europe as it made its way across the sky.The UK Meteor Network confirmed the sighting on Twitter, saying: The fireball... was a Sporadic type with an interesting orbit, in perihelion itaposs inside Mercuryaposs orbit.Went down to km but no meteorite. It was described a leaving a green and blue trail as it entered the Earthaposs atmosphere. Twitter user @SydneyEggbert said: Caught it on my Teslacam last night, driving North on the M near Birmingham.It was spotted in Wakefield, Yorkshire, according to Yorkshire Live, as well as across north Wales and Scotland.But due to the slightly earlier timing of the Leicester photograph, there is uncertainty as to what caused it. It could be a lens flare from a nearby streetlight, a flaming meteor, or something completely dferent altogether.
